context.text: The achievability was proved by pointing out a duality between the BC and MAC channels, which says that the rate region achieved by successive Dirty Paper Coding (DPC, [13]) of BC users' data under a sum power constraint is the same as the capacity region of the dual MAC channel, in which the roles of transmitters and receivers are exchanged, under the same sum power constraint.

The BC channel DPC rate region was established in [14], using the fact that the capacity of the Costa's channel y=x+s+w ([13]), where s is the interference known to the transmitter but not to the receiver, is the same as that of the interference-free channel y=x+w.

context.text: Temporal cooperative sensing has been studied in [5]–[7].
Cooperation among secondary nodes for temporal sensing can overcome problems posed by low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), shadowing, and hidden terminals [7].
A practical solution for cooperative temporal sensing is proposed in [7], whereby individual secondary nodes make decisions about the ON/OFF status of the primary transmitter independently.
In [7], the fusion center is assumed to know the geographic locations of all cooperating secondary nodes and hence can estimate the correlations between their observations.
In [7], a suboptimal temporal detector is proposed based on a linear quadratic (LQ) detector [8], which uses partial statistical knowledge to improve detection performance.
We adopt a model of temporal spectrum sensing similar to the one described in [7].

Temporal spectrum sensing can be formulated as a binary hypothesis testing problem in which the fusion center determines whether or not the current mean received power is higher than the received power when the primary transmitter is in the OFF state [7].
In other words, the system is designed such that (8) is satisfied for the least favorable value of \$\alpha\$, i.e., \$\alpha=\mu\$[7].
The value of this threshold is obtained through simulation [7].

When the observations at the secondary nodes are correlated, the Linear Quadratic (LQ) detector yields a significant performance gain over the CR detector, while still using only partial statistical knowledge about the correlated decision variables [7].

The LQ detector is based on the generalized signal-to-noise ratio or deflection criterion, and makes use of fourth-order statistics under \$H_{0}\$ and second order statistics under \$H_{1}\$ (see [7] for details).
When the correlation between secondary nodes is small and all secondary nodes have the same received SNR, the CR detector outperforms the LQ detector [7].
The LQ detector is seen to clearly outperform CR, which confirms the results in [7].

Under criterion 2, the CR detector outperforms the LQ detector because criterion 2 minimizes the correlation among the observations, and when the correlation is small, the CR detector outperforms the LQ detector according to [7].

context.text: In [16], Puri et al. discuss the challenges faced by any video transmission scheme for wireless sensor networks.
We propose a solution that is best suited to multi-stream coding of video as prevalent in most modem video coding architectures [16].

Predictive video coding (PVC) as used in H.26x or MPEG-x employs two modes in order to encode video: Intra-coding (I) mode exploiting the spatial correlation in the frame that contains the current block by using a block transform such as the discrete cosine transform (DCT), Inter-coding or motion compensated predictive (P) mode that exploits both spatial and temporal correlation in the video sequence [16].

A more recent work on low complexity encoding of sensor video data is characterized by distributed video coding (DVC) which incorporates concepts from source coding with side information, creating an intra-coded I-frame along with a side information counterpart Wyner-Ziv (WZ) frame[16].

context.text: In this paper, we continue with our study of the problem of dirty paper coding (DPC) [1] over the fading dirty paper channel (FDPC) \$Y=H(X+S)+Z\$ that was initiated recently in [2].
In [2], we considered the case of input covariance matrix being positive definite (p.d.).

Those results are restrictive in a sense that if a beamforming and DPC-based transmission scheme is to be used over the Gaussian MIMO BC (beamforming-based schemes are popularly being studied for the BC) then the results of [2] alone will not suffice.
As noted in [2], it is a nonconvex optimization problem and it seems intractable to find an analytical closed-form solution for the optimal inflation factor.

Similar to the minimization problem considered in [2], in this problem also, only the first row and the first column of the block-partitioned matrix in (1), which we call \$M\$, depend on \$W_{(1)}\$.

Thus, an iterative algorithm can now be set up, as done in [2], in which one iteration consists of step-wise minimizations over all the rows of \$W\$ and these iterations are repeated until a good choice is found.
Importantly, this algorithm converges [2].
It can be proved, as done in [2], that the above equation reduces to \${\ BB E}_{H\vert \hat{H}}(A_{1}W+A_{2}^{\ast}H)\Sigma_{S}=0\$, where \$[A_{1}A_{2}^{\ast}]^{\ast}= M^{-1}[I_{m}0]^{\ast}\$.
The scaling factor of \$\min(t,r)\$ is achievable over the no-CSIT FDPC, irrespective of \$\Sigma_{S}\$, when \$\Sigma_{X}\$ is p.d. and it is equal to that of the no-interference upper-bound [2].

However, unlike the case of p.d. covariance matrix [2], now, under p.s.d. input covariance, the difference between the no-interference upper-bound and the achievable rate may not necessarily go to zero in the limit of high SNR.
This follows from Theorem 2 of [2].
Note that Proposition 3 in [2] about the DPC-achievable scaling factor of the no-CSIT Gaussian MIMO BC relies on the use of p.d. input covariance matrix for the last user.
It is proved in [2] that the choice \$W=I_{t}\$ is optimal in the high-SNR regime if \$t\leq r\$.
The achievable-rate expression from [2] can be rewritten to get equation (5) at the bottom of the previous page.
The results of this and our earlier paper [2] make significant progress to address this problem.

.

As in [5], to cope with deep fading, we allow an outage probability of \$P_{out}= {\bf Pr}\left(\Vert {\bf H}_{k}\Vert^{2} < G_{0}\right) = 0.01\$, i.e., user \$k\$ does not transmit if its channel power is below a given threshold \$G_{0}\$.

context.text: In [1], a subblock-wise tracking approach was proposed for single input doubly-selective channels using time-multiplexed (TM) training.
In [2], the approach of [1] has been extended to MIMO channels.

The subblock-wise approaches [1], [2] achieve better performance in fast-fading environments than the approaches based on conventional symbol-wise AR models [3] or block-wise BEM representations [4], [5].
However, the approaches in [1] and [2] used a first-order AR model for BEM coefficients, which is somewhat arbitrary.

Therefore, we propose a subblock-wise MIMO channel tracking as in [2] (and [1] for the corresponding single user case) where we estimate \${\bf h}_{q}(l)\$ in (3) subblock by subblock for their variations, rather than the anew with every non-overlapping block as in [4].

Two finite-memory adaptive filtering algorithms, the exponentially-weighted and the sliding-window recursive least-squares (RLS) algorithm, are considered in [6] for subblock-wise (single input) channel tracking.
In this paper, we extend the approach of [6] to MIMO systems.
Compared to [6] we also provide some guidelines for the selection of the forgetting factor in the exponentially-weighted RLS algorithm.
Now extend the approach of [6] to MIMO systems.

The subblock-wise finite-memory recursive least-squares (RLS) tracking approach of [6] is extended to MIMO channel system, exploiting the oversampled complex exponential basis expansion model (CE-BEM) for the overall channel variations.
Compared to [6] we also provide some guidelines for the selection of the forgetting factor in the exponentially-weighted RLS algorithm.

context.text: The linear precoding scheme based on the geometric mean decomposition (GMD) [5], [6] is introduced.

Recently, the GMD has been proposed in [5], [6] to decompose the \$M\times N\$ matrix \${\mbi H}\$ as \${\mbi H}={\mbi URV}\$, where \${\mbi U}\$ and \${\mbi V}\$ are square unitary matrices, and \${\mbi R}\$ is an \$M\times N\$ real upper triangular matrix with all the diagonal entries equal to the geometric mean of nonzero singular values of \${\mbi H}\$ .
The implementation of GMD is based on the singular value decomposition (SVD) and only requires \${\cal O}((M+N)N)\$ fixed additional operations [5].

context.text: For certain communication environments such as wireless broadcast scenarios where the transmitter equipped with multiantennas to serve multiple non-cooperating users, design of precoding schemes based on the channel state information becomes crucial to exploit the diversity at the receiver [6], [10], [14].
The linear precoding scheme based on the geometric mean decomposition (GMD) [5], [6] is introduced.

Recently, the GMD has been proposed in [5], [6] to decompose the \$M\times N\$ matrix \${\mbi H}\$ as \${\mbi H}={\mbi URV}\$, where \${\mbi U}\$ and \${\mbi V}\$ are square unitary matrices, and \${\mbi R}\$ is an \$M\times N\$ real upper triangular matrix with all the diagonal entries equal to the geometric mean of nonzero singular values of \${\mbi H}\$ .

context.text: Diversity technique has been widely adopted to combat the deleterious wireless channel fading effect [8], [9], [10], [14].
On the other hand, the channel information can also be obtained at the transmitter in some environments, e.g., through feedback in a low-rate channel or a reciprocal channel [14].

For certain communication environments such as wireless broadcast scenarios where the transmitter equipped with multiantennas to serve multiple non-cooperating users, design of precoding schemes based on the channel state information becomes crucial to exploit the diversity at the receiver [6], [10], [14].
Therefore, designing precoders to suppress the channel effect usually leads to better performance than equalization at the receiver [14].
The major problem of the ZF linear precoding scheme is the power enhancement in the unnormalized transmit signal \${\mbi x}\$, which leads to high PAR [14].
Similarly, the DFE based precoding design also suffers from the severe PAR [14] and loses diversity if the transmission power is normalized to one.

In Fig. 3, we plot the performance of GMD-based precoder with the proposed LR-aided ZF-LE, THP scheme [14], LLL-aided THP [13], and IR-LR vector perturbation based on the LLL algorithm in [10] for \$4\times 4\$ i.i.d. systems.

Among many reduced complexity algorithms, the sphere decoding based algorithms provide best candidates for near-capacity performance [7][9][14] The principle of sphere decoding algorithms (SDA) [2] is, instead of an exhaustive search in the lattice formed by all the possible received symbol vectors, it restricts the search to be within a small sphere so that the ML or near-ML solution can be found efficiently.

To produce reliable soft output, the list sphere decoding (LSD) algorithm in [7] applies the max-log approximation to MAP detection by selecting the best vector candidate searched by the sphere decoder.

context.text: In this paper, we are interested in extending the considerations mentioned above to the spectrum sharing multichannel scenario studied in [8] (see Fig. 1).
Reference [8] studies the trade-off at hand between regulation (more primary users) and autonomy (more secondary users) in the absence of cooperation among the secondary users.
Following [8], we first consider an idealistic system with perfect sensing and a simple model for cooperation to gain analytical insight into the impact of secondary cooperation (Sec.
III), for which numerical results and comparison to the noncooperative case [8] are provided in Sec IV.

A cognitive radio network: \$N_{p}\$ primary and \$N_{s}\$ secondary users are uniformly distributed on a disc of radius \$R\$, Each active primary node transmits on its own subchannel, while secondary nodes employ a listen-before-talk mechanism over all subchannels for opportunistic spectrum access [8].

We consider the network model in [8] wherein a frequency band is equally divided into \$N_{p}\$ subchannels, each assigned to one of \$N_{p}\$ primary users1The terms user and node-pair (transmitter-receiver pair) are used interchangeably in this context., and time-slotted.
We extend the analysis in [8], where no cooperation was considered, by assessing the potential gains of secondary cooperation over the non-cooperative case.

To simplify the analysis, we consider, at first, as in [8], perfect sensing (i.e., all secondary users can detect unoccupied channels with no errors), and a collision model where a transmission is successful only in the absence of interference.
We now evaluate the average system sum-throughput, following the same basic notation of [8].
In [8], (2) is evaluated to \$C_{s}^{sum}(i,j)=C_{j}-\left(1-{1 \over i}\right)^{j-1}\$ in the absence of secondary cooperation.
It is noted that for \$R_{coop}=0\$ (no cooperation) equation (4) reduces to the sum-throughput derived in [8] (see (4) therein).

Here, we consider more realistic assumptions on sensing and channel model following Sec III of [8]: (i) imperfect sensing: a secondary user can detect primary transmitters only within a sensing radius \$R_{s}\$ around the user itself (see Fig. 3); (ii) interference model: primary and secondary transmitters and receivers are randomly located in a circular area of radius \$R\$.
Fixed-rate transmissions are attempted by all active transmitters with rate where parameter \$I\$ represents the interference tolerance [8].

context.text: The optimal power allocation strategy for Gaussian multiple-input single-output (MISO) wire-tap channels is studied in [9] and [10].

By somewhat different approaches, both [9] and [10] showed the same result that, under the relatively simpler MISO setting, the optimization problem can be transformed into the well-known Rayleigh quotient problem and thus can be solved analytically.

In a very recent paper, Oggier et al. [11] showed that the perfect secrecy capacity of general MIMO wire-tap channels is achieved by Gaussian signaling, thus showing the secrecy capacity inner bound in [9] is tight.

This is because the power allocation problem for MIMO wire-tap channels is non-convex and, unlike simple MISO cases [9], [10], there does not exist a simple way to get around the complex problem structure.

context.text: We develop our algorithm by using a state-of-the-art global optimization technique called branch and bound with reformulation-linearization technique (BB/RLT) [12].

The motivation of using BB/RLT is that BB/RLT guarantees the convergence to a global optimal solution for any nonconvex optimization problem as long as the feasible region of the problem is compact (see [12] for further details).

In BB/RLT, partitioning variables are those that are involved in nonlinear terms, for which we have therefore defined new variables, and whose bounding intervals will need to be partitioned during the BB process [12].

context.text: As described in [3], if the links are assumed to be error-free and hence there is no need for retransmission, energy-efficient routing algorithms choose the minimum-hop paths in cases in which the transmitter power is fixed.

Two types of retransmission schemes, namely end-to-end retransmission (EER) and hop-by-hop retransmission (HHR), are elaborated in [3] and [4], where the relationship between the link error probabilty of individual links and the overall number of retransmissions needed to ensure reliable packet delivery is established.
In [3], the authors designed energy-efficient routing algorithms in the network layer by also taking into account the link layer retransmission probabilities and energies.

Optimization of the one-hop transmission distance without retransmission mechanism is studied in [5] while optimal routing with retransmission mechanism considering EER and HHR models is investigated [3].

context.text: There has been interest in deterministic Compressed Sensing (CS) RIP matrix constructions ever since the introduction of universal near-optimal randomized constructions [3].

In this case standard compressed sensing (CS) methods [3], [5], [9], [7] deal with recovering the \$k\$ most significant entries of \$\Psi\cdot {\bf A}\$ using only a small (i.e., compressed) set of measurements given by \${\cal M}\cdot\Psi\cdot {\bf A}\$, where \${\cal M}\$ is a special type of rectangular \$K\times N\$ matrix with the Restricted Isometry Property (RIP).

Given a \${\rm RIP} (N,O(k),\epsilon)\$ matrix \${\cal M}\$ with \$\epsilon\in\left(0, {1 \over 2}\right)\$ sufficiently small, a near optimal \$O(k)\$-term approximation can be obtained for \$\Psi\cdot {\bf A}\$ using linear programming [3], [5] or Regularized Orthogonal Matching Pursuit (ROMP) variants [9], [7].

context.text: For example, radio frequency sensing and control networks deployed on naval vessels must maintain connectivity across multiple watertight bulkheads [1].

Prior research into the use of ultrasonic signals for transmitting data across metallic barriers has shown that echoing of acoustic energy within the channel leads to significant inter-symbol interference when transmitting at high data rates [1].
By passing the pulses to be transmitted through a suitable predistortion filter placed in front of the transmitting transducer, it has been demonstrated that echo amplitude can be decreased [1].

Under the assumption that the echoes in Figure 2 are time shifted, amplitude scaled versions of the primary received pulse (the approach taken in [1]), the theoretical ideal cancelation pulse is a copy of the primary excitation pulse delayed in time and amplitude (assuming channel linearity).

context.text: Various solutions have been proposed to improve communication speed and reliability in the shallow water acoustic channel; e.g., direct sequence spread spectrum modems coupled with matching pursuit algorithms have produced data rates of 161 bps in 2 to 4 meter water over a range of 440 meters [1]; multiple phase coherent receivers using QPSK and channel coding have transmitted information at 6,700 bps over ranges of 2 kilometers [2]; PPC and DBPSK have been used to achieve data rates up to about 2.2 kbps in shallow water [3] at ranges of about 2 kilometers, and orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) has also been used to transmit data in the shallow underwater acoustic channel [4].

context.text: Various solutions have been proposed to improve communication speed and reliability in the shallow water acoustic channel; e.g., direct sequence spread spectrum modems coupled with matching pursuit algorithms have produced data rates of 161 bps in 2 to 4 meter water over a range of 440 meters [1]; multiple phase coherent receivers using QPSK and channel coding have transmitted information at 6,700 bps over ranges of 2 kilometers [2]; PPC and DBPSK have been used to achieve data rates up to about 2.2 kbps in shallow water [3] at ranges of about 2 kilometers, and orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) has also been used to transmit data in the shallow underwater acoustic channel [4].

Shallow water communication experiments employing PPC and DBPSK in Puget Sound, WA, are described in [3]; the length of time the channel model remained satisfactory was influenced by a variety of factors and ranged from a half second to many seconds.

The present paper extends the work in [3] in two ways: first, we employ rate 1/2 IRA codes to improve system reliability, and second, we replace the hard-decision DBPSK demodulator used in [3] with a SISO DBPSK demodulator based on [7], and employ iterative demodulation and channel decoding.

context.text: The present paper extends the work in [3] in two ways: first, we employ rate 1/2 IRA codes to improve system reliability, and second, we replace the hard-decision DBPSK demodulator used in [3] with a SISO DBPSK demodulator based on [7], and employ iterative demodulation and channel decoding.

Through use of a linear phase estimation combined with squaring and phase unwrapping, we greatly reduce the number of trellis states required compared to the scheme originally proposed for fading channels in [7].
We modified the BCJR's \$\gamma\$ state transition metric by adopting the metric proposed by Lodge for a DBPSK MAP demodulator [7] to accept the channel prediction from the / linear predictor.
A comparison of the methods presented above to the demodulator scheme described by Hoeher and Lodge in [7] illustrates the improvement in computational complexity provided by the linear predictor.

The algorithm described in [7] requires that the trellis be expanded to \$M^{N}\$ states with \$M\$ branches per state. \$M\$ is the number of points in the signal constellation (2 for DBPSK) and \$N\$ is the desired phase predictor order.

context.text: Digital post-compensation of optical fiber transmission impairments was recently proposed based on coherent detection and digital signal processing (DSP) [1]–[3].

The basic idea is to coherently detect and sample the received optical field, followed by either a backward propagation simulation of the sampled field [1], [3], or by digital phase conjugation and propagation of the resulting field through the original link using simulation [2].

Inter-symbol interference caused by the interaction between Kerr nonlinearity and fiber chromatic dispersion can be equalized, and effects caused by ASE noise such as nonlinear phase noise can be reduced [1]–[4].
Also, please note only the backward propagation equalization [1], [3] is studied in this work.

Due to the broadband nature of fiber optic communication systems with single channel communication rate on the order of \$10\ {\rm Gb/s}\$, reducing the number of required computations is of utmost importance in eventual realization of the digital post-compensation method, as pointed out in [1].

The term admittance and the notation Y is used to denote the ratio of the numerical value of two waves regardless of their nature.
